thread.title: Exeter might get something better than Princesshay Leisure on the bus station site - but only if we ask people what they want

author: Patrick Phelvin
title: Exeter might get something better than Princesshay Leisure on the bus station site - but only if we ask people what they want
text:
Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Comments 
There’s no getting away from it, the fact that the Crown Estate has pulled out of the plan to redevelop part of Exeter’s bus station is a bitter blow to the city’s ambitions. 
The worst part is that sound enterprises have been uprooted and forced to find new premises. One, Hyde + Seek, has spent £20,000 on finding a new city centre shop for a development that is no longer going ahead. 
The Conservative Party has been quick to criticise a city council leadership which has very little to show for the £4million of public money it has spent on the project to date. Read More Five things we would like to see in Exeter now the £100m development plan has collapsed 
But the fact that it’s no longer happening owes more to Brexit than any council incompetence. 
And it’s important to remember that the Labour Party stood for election against the Tories, and won, with the city centre development at the heart of its vision for the city. TH Real Estate and The Crown Estate's extension of Princesshay Shopping Centre on a large section of the bus and coach station site 
When the dust has settled, it’s vital that all politicians, regardless of their party, work together for the benefit of the city. Hopefully they will realise what an opportunity lies before us. 
The Princesshay shopping extension looks dead and buried and there’s now a big question mark over the leisure centre which, with the bus station, is going to cost in excess of £40million. Read More 
In order to move forward it’s important that minds are opened. Perhaps a Passivhaus pool is not what people want – or are prepared to pay for? St Sidwell's Point in Exeter City Centre 
And instead of outlets that only generic high street retailers can afford we could have an market for small traders at less than half the price. Whisper it, but it’s possible that the Crown Estate decision is a blessing in disguise. 
But if we’re going back to the drawing board, the council must ensure that the people of Exeter – some of whom felt left out of the last plan – are asked to sketch out the first lines. Like us on Facebook
